technical_appreciation: It is a subtile process. Men know men, they cite men, the propose men for awards, they chose men for their team, the mentor men, they write better letters of recommendations for men. So the appreciation is constantly given more to men and than to women.
technical_appreciation_solution:
When I was studying I thought it is all about competence. Only after time I found out about the other factors of networking and so on. 
As a doctoral student I did not have the problem so much as I was quite successful.
In the years as professor it was more difficult as I was now competing for resources, H-Index, Grants and so on. It took my years to get a standing there. 
But there were also  two male mentors who helped.
technical_researcher_solution: Observing it, trying to understand the game, be prepared and taking opportunities next time, next meeting ....

technical_appreciation: no additional comments - the yes said all.
technical_researcher: sure. Who has not? And moreover, there are only very few networking women. However, almost all successful men are networking. In contrast: females who have gained a position are often eager to bite other woman away. Sad but true.

label: Self_confidence/Parenting
technical_publications: Oh yes, and it's even worth with grant applications. Grant applications are written by the colleagues but on the cover sheet are only mentioned the names of the PIs who already have a professorship. I really hate that doing the work but getting no credit for it!!! At my institution it is an unwritten rule that regardless of input and work at an article the directors always mentioned at last. It just sucks and as long as the BMBF or DFG don't change the rules regarding cover sheets on grant applications and more stern regrding authorship nothing will change.
technical_researcher: Constantly, also explained in more detail before.

technical_appreciation: more visible, get invited to debates etc.
technical_others: Most male colleagues are so much better at asking for stuff, being loud and getting heard

technical_publications_solution: Private meetings to discuss problems with boss

technical_ideasharing: many conferences where i can share my ideasare not allowd for me
label: Restricted_access

technical_researcher: Yes, it decreased though in the last years.

technical_publications_solution: I had to wait 4 years to publish my work.  - but i did in the end, because i did not give up.

technical_appreciation: Some male researchers I met are just more confident in "selling" their work and thus get more appreciation, whereas I recognized in myself (but also some other female researchers) we are more critical about our own work.
technical_appreciation_solution: I don't get "bedazzled" by some bragging anymore and try to be more appreciative of my successes and my hard work .

technical_publications: Yes, many times. I think every researcher does so.

technical_researcher: No concrete situation. Just sometimes had the impression that results or presentations by female researchers were questioned more strongly than that of male researchers.
technical_researcher_solution: Trying to paint too much attention to it

technical_ideasharing: This is dependent to th sturcture of my PhD. A (male) colleaque at my institute has the same problem.
label: Not_only_female

technical_others: Womens achievements are not visible if only initials are qouted
technical_others_solution: Giving whole names, wherever it is possible. In public talks, I emphasize womens achievements as examples for successful results.

technical_ideasharing: Everybody are bussy and my profs supervised many doctoral students. So he hast to share his resources.
label: Not_only_female

technical_researcher_solution: Initiative of university to prefer hiring females/members of underrepresented or minority groups in case of equal qualification

technical_publications: "struggle" with seniors that had to be put in author list. However, it was not a matter of gender more of seniority and prestige. some disiciplines are more title and prestige oriented than others...

technical_ideasharing:
This also happens, because some women do not take part in discussions, or men just start talking, while women are waiting to be next.
However, younger women sometimes seem to be more present. And this also heavily depends on the character.
label: Self_confidence/Visibility

technical_ideasharing: difficulty to attend conferences when parenting
label: Parenting

technical_ideasharing: Every week in the project meetings, we have some "alpha men" in our group, who like to talk a lot and they don't pay any attention to my try to speak.
label: Self_confidence/Visibility
technical_publications:
Oh yes. I once worked with a male professor, who forced us to give him the first authorship, what we did.
In my case, men would always like to write their names on it because they have contributed something. And that's despite the fact that some of them have previously claimed that my subject area is "soft" and uninteresting. But when they realise that the field does lead to publications, they think they belong on the paper because they were there at a meeting and gave their opinion.
technical_publications_solution: I have a great supervisor (male) and a female mentor, who help me to stay confident.
technical_researcher: As already said in the research project I'm working on are some loud and confident male persons, they tend to get priority in the meetings, because they argue loud and often about their needs.
technical_researcher_solution: I need to schedule extra meetings with some partners for my work.

technical_appreciation: Yes, as they seem more intelligent and competent.
technical_appreciation_solution: Show that every one should be rated according to his/her qualification.

technical_ideasharing: I was for instance recommended to not present my results in the group and at conferences because it was not perfect. Men can present non-perfect results, but I would not stand the critics I would get. So, to protect my feelings, I was not allowed to present my results although I wanted.
label: Expertise_perception
technical_appreciation:
The results of men are real results, my results were often not believed to be mine. For instance, I was told they were too good, they must stem from someone else with more competence than I can have. 
This happend the stronger, the more qualified I was. I suppose it was because my results improved, so the difference between what they expect from a woman and of what I deliver was larger.
technical_publications:
We had a male colleague who squeezed into the author list although he had not worked on the paper at all. He just allowed his (female) PhD student to publish it.
I had also problems publishing, was not always allowed to publish my results.
technical_researcher: Yes, all the time. People say it is eithcal to give them priority. They need unlimited jobs and high salaries to nourish their familiy and build a house. I as a woman can become a housewife. So, I need no job at all, can do research at my kitchen table.

technical_appreciation: Sometimes this happens but for the issue I mentioned before of being in minority.
technical_others: If you see architectural couples working together, normally the men is a PhD and the woman no. Research needs time and concentration and it is difficult the conciliation with family.

technical_publications: It was hierarchical issue, not because of gender.

technical_others: Organisational aspects in a collaborative project fall to me when I am the only woman on the team. It is also hard to be aggressive and assertive when working with an all-male team. I feel like I also have to push harder to get the same level of support in a collaborative project in comparison to a male colleague.
technical_others_solution: I ask other male colleagues / supervisor to help with pushing other male colleagues in a collaborative setting.

technical_appreciation: Sometimes, I felt like I am not even seen as part of the project, although I was the key initiator. Male researchers with equally or less successful PhDs were called genius and highly valuable etc., I was just that one woman on the team.
technical_appreciation_solution: I am not working there any longer ;)
technical_researcher: Who was invited to give talks often was a decision based on someone knew a guy even though there were more successful women who could have talked about the same thing
technical_others: Not sure whether this is of interest but I was explicitly mentioned in the realm of research projects I wasn't part of, just so the project looked more diverse. Me explicitly saying that I don't want this was just ignored.
